This isn't true, although it's possible it's a regression.  R1000_Chassis is an example of a chassis with dual rotor fans.  Can you please look at it and see if that mechanism works for you?

Sorry I missed an important note.
I have tried the 'BindConnector' you mentioned. It didn't work because:
My board uses the interrupt pin differently than the community when using the chip PCA9555 (it's not designed to use the interrupt pin). As a result, FanSensor cannot obtain gpiochip information normally.
I modified the commit msg.

Does your dts enable https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/devicetree/bindings/input/gpio-keys-polled.txt

That generally lets userspace receive an interrupt on something that the kernel handles polling for.
Did you delete the old method, so even if the HW supports interrupt, it only polls periodically? The old method needs to be preserved

As written, this moves ALL systems to polling, regardless of whether they're capable of polling or not.  For this to make it on master, it needs to add some kind of detection logic to determine if the GPIO in question can be interrupred, and fall back to polling only in the case where the gpio didn't support interrupts.
This is used multiple places, consider add a member variable for it
Use weak_ptr to prevent accessing invalid pointers
Could there be an invalid pointer here?
The answer is "It depends", but it's not possible for weak_ptr to be incorrect.
I am unable to understand why the pointer is valid that depends. However, some codes using "class TachSensor: public enable_shared_from_this<TachSensor>" to resolve the issue.
I am revising this now. After adding ' public enable_shared_from_this<PresenceSensor>' and related codes, it cannot start normally. a little puzzled
Could you share some error messages to me? bmcWeb applied "enable_shared_from_this" to solve asynchronous problems.
It didn't even give an error... just silently stopped working. I don't understand why it returns a nullptr after weakptr.lock()...
if weakptr.lock() returns nullptr then your object has been destructed.

NOUSE?

Also ifdef'ing this feels a bit antiquated and requires multiple builds with different build flags to ensure the code still behaves as required. Please split this out into two different PresenceSensor implementations that can *both* be compiled into the one binary, and select them some other way.
+1 to both the typo and runtime selection.  Can we just fall back to polling when we get an error code opening the char device?

Sorry. I didn't see your comment when submitting PS7.

Now I am confused how to implement your comment.
The main thing is 'how to determine' whether to switch the gpio usage.

One way is to have the build switch dictate which implementation gets instantiated rather than which implementation gets compiled. Another way might be to pass an option on the command line or in the environment.

A fancier option would be to request GPIO events, and if that fails, perform the request again but without requiring a line event and fall back to polling. The request should fail if the gpiochip does not implement an irqchip. With this I think you could get away with a single implementation.

> One way is to have the build switch dictate which implementation gets instantiated rather than which implementation gets compiled. Another way might be to pass an option on the command line or in the environment.
> 
> A fancier option would be to request GPIO events, and if that fails, perform the request again but without requiring a line event and fall back to polling.
 The request should fail if the gpiochip does not implement an irqchip. With this I think you could get away with a single implementation.

The last option would be my preference, and given how we've handled other situations like this in the past (like hwmon device creation), would be the general answer especially given that including the polling code has no unintended side effects.
Please don't make this a configure option.  We should be able to runtime determine if the gpio in question supports interrupts.

I'm not sure about this part...
Since I don't have a suitable machine here to test. Hope the reviewers have better opinions.

I'm not quite following why this needed to change.  I'm assuming that gpioLine.request fails on your system?  So I would've expected that the existing code remain largely as is, but in the catch handler on line 237 of the old code, when the request fails, we would just re-init the structures to use polling.  Does that not work?

Why do we have to explicitly request a line read?

Also, the docs for this say:
This function will block if no event was queued for this line.

Which doesn't seem like it would work for what we need to do.

Are you changing the EM schema here? If so, that's not what we should be doing at all. You can implement this test entirely inside the PresenceSensor class with no external input. You need to first request the GPIO with line events enabled, and if that fails, request it again without line events (but fall back to polling)

> Are you changing the EM schema here? If so, that's not what we should be doing at all. You can implement this test entirely inside the PresenceSensor class with no external input. You need to first request the GPIO with line events enabled, and if that fails, request it again without line events (but fall back to polling)

+1
I didn't understand what you meant before... Please take a look at the current way is what you think is correct.
This is the approach I was looking for, thanks! With that out of the way though, I have some concerns about the implementation details.
How does this interact with the `status` class member?

There is no direct interaction. Only sync changes where all 'status' changes.

Because of multiple confirmations in the 'monitorPre..' method, such a map is needed to record the current status of all fans.
With the current code, it is indeed possible to remove this map.Please give me some time to test it.

Why not merge this code into initGpio()? I don't see a reason to have this indirection through the eventListenSupport class member as a means to determine which of these methods we should invoke.

i.e. let's delete eventListenSupport.
got it. I will fix it.
Can we swap this with line 301, and then use assign into gpioPresValueMap in terms of `status`?

This becomes

 if (status)
 
right?

But what does that even mean? According to the code below, if `status` evaluates true then you do logFanInserted(), in which case `status` should be renamed to `fanInserted`.
This method really is a mash of highly coupled variables. I don't like it at all. Can we discuss how to pare this down so we maintain the minimum amount of state necessary to get the job done?

I also think this nesting is a bit complicated. The original purpose was to avoid adding new variables.
So, maybe add a variable sensorName to the PresenceSensor to identify it?
Let's discuss this after you've posted your rework in accordance with the comments above.
After some testing, I think it is indeed better to use two different PresenceSensors. So it changed to what it looks like now. The test has passed.

Not a huge fan of the std::optional<bool>, and I'm wondering whether we just throw the request exception out of the PresenceSensor constructor instead, catch it in the calling code and then fall back to PollingPresenceSensor in the catch block.

What do you think?
We want to catch all exceptions here?
Please don't log this.  THis is expected on systems that need to poll.

Please don't make this a global.

https://github.com/isocpp/CppCoreGuidelines/blob/master/CppCoreGuidelines.md#Ri-global

Please find a way to structure your code such that global variables like this are not required.
Why is this anything other than 1?  Are the lines not debounced?
The original intention of adding this is to reduce the impact of frequent manual  plugging and unplugging in a short period of time.
Shouldn't the delay time cover that?
this is the equivalent of find(), but is duplicating the lookup.
?  If the GPIO fails to read, the fan isn't inserted?  That doesn't seem right.
The default property is true. Can't keep the default property doing nothing, right? At least modify its status to let users know that this fan is having problems.
This isn't modifying the status though, it's saying the fan got unplugged.  I would expect this to be a shutdown.

> event_read never detecting signal changes

From your commit message. In this case, which call throw exception? This throw allows you to create polling PSensor right?
Since function has multiple places to fail. Return error or true/false

gpio is inserted to map even if try on gpioLine.request fails 
Is this expected behavior?
What is the logic behind confirmTimes ??
